newsitem.title: FRANCE: French n-plant measures unwarranted - safety agency.
newsitem.headline: French n-plant measures unwarranted - safety agency.

text.p: A French nuclear safety agency said on Wednesday that a temporary ban imposed last week on yachting and fishing around the La Hague nuclear reprocessing plant on the Cherbourg peninsula was unwarranted.

In a report requested by the government, the French Office of Protection against Ionising Radiation (OPRI) said a more limited ban on activity within 50 metres (yards) of a pipe spewing nuclear waste into the English Channel would suffice to protect human health in the area.
It said its testing found "no significant increase" in radioactivity levels in the zone, as the waste being dumped into the water were quickly diluted to levels of radioactivity found in nature.
The La Hague plant is run by state nuclear company Cogema.
Environment Minister Dominique Voynet last week announced emergency safety measures for the zone, saying she would not wait for the completion of the state study.

Voynet, head of France's Greens party and a minister in the new leftist government which took power five weeks ago, described the step as "precautionary" and said it had not yet been established that there was a danger to health.
The Greenpeace environmental group says it has found radioactivity levels exceeding European Union limits in the water and sediment near the plant's discharge pipe.
A study by French scientists made public in January found a concentration of leukaemia cases in patients under 25 years old and living within 35 km (20 miles) of La Hague.
